body.value: Direct Answer: Answering question from childhood experience. Sosa's father used to read her the newspapers.
Direct Answer: Answering question from middle school experience, Sosa did not pick up newspaper after her father died.
Direct Answer: Answering question from university experience, Sosa's was in a class that referred to number of papers. She was fascinated with the ideas.
Conclusion Answer: Sosa drawing conclusions that her interest in journalism began with her childhood experience.
Direct Answer: Sosa reminiscing the newspaper coverages in her childhood, there are rarely coverages on hispanics, because there are simply not much Hispanic lawmakers or teachers.

Background Information and Reflective Answer: Former attorney in UT Austin make it possible for hispanic students to go to colleges, it was awakening for Sosa. She realized there should be coverages about Hispanics on newspaper.
Direct Answer: Coverage on newspaper were defensive, there were no coverage on who is involved in the movements.
Direct Answer: It was Corpus Christi Caller Times.
Direct Answer: Sosa thinks her father was rather using newspaper to educate her in her father's own way rather than commenting.
Reflective Answer: Sosa do not think she had any conversations about politics or political movements with her peers or teachers in her early school life.
Direct Answer: There were no conversations about hispanic movements at high school due to majority of the students there were white, and came from wealthier families.
Direct Answer: Sosa think it was natural for her to choose so.
Direct Answer: It was also because the pressure from Plan II, and her mother convinced her to choose a more practical major, so she chose French. Sosa Smiled.
Direct Answer: Sosa reminiscing her time with her friends and her career in France, and how she liked French.
Direct Answer: Sosa realized she wanted to be a journalist while she was at Stanford pursuing MPA degree.
Background Answer: First it was because Sosa's roommate back to UT was a niece of a professor at Stanford. She became interested in Stanford after the campus visit.
Direct Answer: Sosa decided to go to Stanford after seeing the courses catalog, she thought it was social conscious.
Direct Answer: Sosa had the chance to volunteer for Cesar Chavez campaign due to professors' introduction.
Reflective Answer: It was a transformation experience for Sosa, and she spoke highly of the professors and the courses offered in Stanford.
Cooperating Answer: Sosa did not remember any of the names, but she said she will find it if she find any transcripts.
In-depth Follow-up Question: Interviewer asked how did Sosa gained journalistic skills as the courses at Stanford are not related to journalism (skills such as objectivity).
Reflective Answer: Sosa indirectly practice her journalistic skills while volunteering at Cesar Chavez campaign, but she said she wasn't an expert yet.
Direct Answer: Sosa went to worked for New York Times, and later coincidentally had the chance to speak for the press for Cesar Chavez. Sosa smiled.
Direct Answer: Sosa remembered there were proposition dropped in mailboxes that were prohibited to do without authorizations. She thought it was unfair.
Direct Answer: Volunteers was not leaving materials on mailboxes, and these propositions are the only ways that farmers could get their messages out in California at that time.
Reflective Answer: Media in California was not presenting issues in a fair and balanced way.
Direct Answer: Sosa remembered they volunteered to canvass on streets to distribute Hispanic candidates' political campaigns in San Jose and other places.
Direct Answer: They handed out the promotional materials and tried hard to skirt the issue, the volunteers are all students, mostly from Stanford.
Direct Answer: There were four students that Sosa could think of in the program, she also mentioned there were other Latino students on campus.
Direct Answer: Sosa smiled. Sosa and other Latino students have regular activity group and they went to journalism gatherings together.

Reflective Answer: Sosa mentioned a interesting time at Northern California: New communications or software companies were forming, and they opened their lawns to students, which helped them to form close friendships
Direct Answer: These companies are identified as liberal by the students, and these companies thought it was important for the students to be responsible journalists in the future.
Direct Answer: Sosa think Austin have always been open, and there were free thinking in and out of campus.
Consistent Direct Answer: Sosa remembered dining in her college roommates Stanford aunt home with the faculty, the conversations were always open and connected.
Direct Answer: Sosa have begun to experience the same openness and connectedness in Austin, and she wanted more of it.
Reflective Answer: Sosa mentioned she always want to to be in a group where journalism could help look at occurring things and shape them no matter which part of the country she is in.

Reflective Answer: Sosa thinks journalism helps to shape conversations, and in larger journalism organizations like NYT, you are shaping the thoughts around the globe. Sosa wants to be a part of that.
Direct Answer: Sosa does not remembered the coverages exactly. But Sosa mentioned she would talked the Hispanic issues with her friends.
Relative Answer: Sosa helped the Hispanics running for offices, and help them to explain to Hispanic crowds in California about political issues and their positions.
Consistent Direct Answer: Sosa mentioned people the interviewer could reach out to to confirm she have involved in the campaigns.
Direct Answer: Sosa do not think they are only associated with farm workers, they are running for offices, not farm workers.
Direct Answer: Sosa have talked to the farm workers about their rights as a volunteer in San Jose, even they are not citizens and can not run for offices.
Indirect Answer: Sosa could not remember this information. She mentioned another person "Alex" that recruited her and taught them how to speak to crowds. She think Alex remember these information.
Indirect Answer: Sosa do not remembered any of them because it has been too long, but she did remembered these candidates were running for local offices instead of state offices.
Direct Answer: Sosa went home to Corpus Christi and applied for a job at the local newspaper.
Direct Answer: Sosa was covering women's section at first, mainly covering wedding announcements and some social issues related to women interests.
Direct Answer: Sosa was later reassigned to be a music writer in the 70s, but she did not remember the exact time.
Relative Answer: WIllie Nelson was very popular in Texas, especially in Corpus Christi, and Sosa would be sent a cover his shows/ stories when he came down for concerts.
Relative Answer: Sosa remembered Nelson was arranging her behind the stage to cover the stories because Nelson is protecting her from the beer bottles thrown to the stage.

Relative Answer: Sosa remembered Nelson or his friends would call and pick Sosa up whenever he is in town for concerts. Nelson will ask Sosa if she will cover the story. Sosa enjoyed being a music writer.
Direct Answer: Sosa was converted to a news writer when a new executive editor came in, and she covered general news for about six years.
Direct Answer: Sosa later moved to Florida with a managing editor and hired as a Metro editor.

Direct Answer: Sosa did not really wanted to be in women's news section at first. But one of her mentor told her she has to start somewhere, and people do move around in news departments all the time.
Direct Answer: Sosa mentioned Nancy Stanford, who was the one who hired her at The Caller Times. Nancy and her husband later become Sosa's lifetime friends.
Relative Answer: Nancy and her husband came from very wealthy families. Journalism were their hobbies although they are very serious journalists.
Relative Answer: Nancy and her husband later left the newspaper business and moved to Paris for about 5 years
Relative Answer:  Nancy and her husband bought a cruise ship and outfitted it as an apartment.
Relative Answer:  Nancy and her husband later travelled to southwestern France in the boat, and Sosa would come down with them during free time in Summer. They were like family to Sosa.
Direct Answer: Nancy was covering civil rights movement before she was the editor of women's section.Sosa wanted to be some version of Nancy because Nancy has such a influence on her.
Direct Answer: There were not many women in that section, and there was one high profile woman who was the social editor and has a column.
Relative Answer:The column covers big parties and the guests, as well as important people working in oil industry, because many of them live in Corpus Christi.
Relative Answer: Sosa also covered the first woman Air Force General in the women's news section, so the section is not just about wedding announcements.
Reflective Answer: Sosa thinks the newspaper sent a female reporter instead of male reporter to cover the story was interesting, because the general was a big figure. Sosa smiled.
Direct Answer: The newspaper will cover the Garcia family routinely because they are influential and important, and White people see it as windows to Hispanic communities.
Direct Answer: There were only Hispanic reporters at first who later became editors, but it was much years later.
Direct Answer: Most of the Hispanic reporters were general news reporter.
Direct Answer: Sosa's answer was no. There were many veteran reporters and she is far from being the first Hispanic reporter at the local newspaper.
Direct Answer: Lakeland was an upper city, and Sosa do not think there were any Hispanic reporter that she know. The only Hispanics contacts she knew was the farm workers.
Direct Answer: Sosa's editor asked her if she will be comfortable working in a community that was majorly white people.
Direct Answer: Sosa do not think she had problems with that, since she have lived and studied in Anglo communities all the time.
Direct Answer: Sosa do not think she met any resistance from the newspaper.
Direct Answer: There were reports related to the general economic or social issues regarding to the farmers, but there were no direct reports about them.
In-depth direct answer: Sosa remembered her colleague tried to write reports about the farmers' living conditions in Central Florida.
Direct Answer: There were only the living conditions reports or economics report, but no other reports than those.
Direct Answer: Lakeland is in the middle of Orlando and Tampa, it is an inland city.
Direct Answer: Sosa does not think it was impacted since it is an upper middle class community, and there were not a lot of political coverage on the paper.
Direct Answer: Sosa think Lakeland was a wealthy community, and the influential people have characterized the community in some way.
Direct Answer: Sosa do not think there were a lot of politics going on in Lakeland other than social events.
Direct Answer: Sosa have spent around 16 months at Lakeland.
Direct answer: Sosa went to Chicago Sun Times after that.
Direct Answer: It was a huge shift for Sosa in so many ways as Sosa have never lived in such a big city, and there was a strong journalism community at Chicago back then.
Relative Answer: Sosa remembered the reporter would convene at Billy Joe's and drink until the early in the next morning, it was a new experience for Sosa.
Direct Answer: Sosa think Chicago was a revelation to her and she enjoyed the journalism environment in Chicago. She knew she wanted to stay in journalism when she moved to Chicago.
Relative Answer:The reporters always talk about politics in the bars, and Chicago inspired Sosa to be a lifelong journalist.
Direct Answer: Sosa was first a cover editor at CST, her main job was to develop an instinct about what is important to cover. A year later they asked if Sosa wanted to be an reporter.
Relative answer: Sosa's first assignment as a reporter was to cover Jewish and Japanese communities in Chicago. It was fascinating to Sosa.

Reflective Answer: Sosa realized how much government can do for the two groups of people she covered, and she reflected on the Hispanic community was never quite brought up by the white community back in Texas.

Reflective Answer: The experience was awakening to Sosa and became more interested in covering ethnic communities. She wanted to write about the Hispanic communities, but it wasn't big enough to cover in editor's views.
Direct Answer: There were not really an opportunity to cover the latinos in a political sense because the mayor were not Hispanic. And they will only report Hispanic news if there were riots.
Direct answer: They will not cover Hispanic reports unless they community newspaper have serious reports about Hispanic political presence.
Clarifying Answer: It was more like unrest instead of riots, there were no injuries or takeovers, there were no big events like this will be picked up by larger newspapers.

Direct answer: There was only two Hispanic reporter at Chicago at that time. There was an Hispanic reporter at CST before Sosa who later went to New York to work for a journalistic polling organization.
Indirect Answer: Sosa answered she would try to think of the name.
In-depth Follow-up Question: Asking Sosa if her publisher have any contact with the spanish language newspaper. (Very blur audio)
Direct answer: The CST tried to appeal to the Hispanic community and get them to read the paper.
Direct Answer: CST had a spanish language tabloid named "Pacino" and named Sosa as the editor. But the local Spanish newspaper hated that, because they hated the competitions.
Direct Answer:  The tabloid died in a year, killed by CST instead of the spanish newspaper competitions. They have met too much resistance and being criticized of not being Hispanic enough.
Direct answer: The spanish community resented the puran tinge in "Pacino", Sosa tried to think if she should edit it to Mexican Spanish. But the languages are very different in different places.
Direct answer: The response from the Spanish community was straight- they did not want "Pacino" to exist. The CST don't have to step in their realm.
Direct answer: Sosa really enjoyed editing newspaper. Her reporter were covering stories that English paper wasn't covering. But some people in CST resisted Spanish stories in their paper.

In-depth Direct answer: There were complaints from English readers that CST shouldn't cover Hispanic communities' stories, and also complaints from Hispanic communities because they think it is too Cuban. So the resistance was inside and out.
Direct answer: Sosa do not think she have the answer. CST was simply receiving these complaints and the editors never told her why. There might be many reasons behind this.
